Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.raw_text: Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973)
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, landlords have a duty to maintain residential premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code and to refrain from acts or omissions that substantially interfere with tenants’ quiet enjoyment. See Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mass. 184 (1973).
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.support_reasoning: The excerpt is from a concurrence/dissent, not the majority, but it squarely recognizes that, under the court’s new approach in Hemingway, landlords have an obligation to comply with the State Sanitary Code for the benefit of tenants and that their duty to provide and maintain premises meeting those minimum legal standards is tied to the tenant’s rent obligation. The opinion also acknowledges tenants’ statutory and common‑law protections against interferences with their tenancy (e.g., constructive eviction/quiet enjoyment) even though that portion is more implicit in this excerpt. Because this is not the main majority text but does accurately describe the rule being adopted, it provides moderate support for the proposition.
Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, 363 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “I would reverse that rule and hold instead (a) that the various statutes, ordinances, by-laws, rules, regulations and codes prescribing minimum standards for dwelling units impose on the landlord, for the benefit of his tenants, an obligation to comply with those minimum standards, and (b) that by renting such a unit the landlord impliedly agrees with his tenant (i) that at the time of the renting the unit complies with those standards and (ii) that during the term of the renting he will do whatever such legal provisions require him to do for compliance with such standards.”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284–85 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease or tenancy in Massachusetts. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284–85 (1994); Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715–16 (1977).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and what constitutes a breach, but it does not state that the covenant is implied in every residential lease or tenancy in Massachusetts. The case assumes the existence of the covenant and analyzes whether the landlord’s conduct breached it; it does not articulate the broad doctrinal proposition that such a covenant is implied in all residential tenancies. Blackett v. Olanoff, not this case, is the better authority for that specific proposition.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 186, § 14, provides, in relevant part, that ‘any lessor or landlord who directly or indirectly interferes with the quiet enjoyment of any residential premises by the occupant’ shall be punished by a fine or imprisonment, and also shall be subject to liability to the tenant for damages arising from the interference. This section also confers on the Superior and District Courts the authority in equity to restrain violations of its provisions. Id.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is implied in every residential lease or tenancy in Massachusetts. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284–85 (1994); Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715–16 (1977).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly recognizes an implied covenant (or warranty) of quiet enjoyment and applies it to residential tenants, but it does not state that such a covenant is implied in every residential lease or tenancy in Massachusetts. The court assumes the existence of an implied covenant and analyzes whether it was breached; the universal, across-the-board formulation in the proposition is supplied more explicitly by later cases such as Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority, not by this decision itself.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 715\.relevant_excerpt: "The defendant in each of these consolidated actions for rent successfully raised constructive eviction as a defense against the landlords’ claim. The judge found that the tenants were ‘very substantially deprived’ of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises ‘for a substantial time’ (emphasis original). He ruled that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated... The landlords argue that they did not violate the tenants’ implied covenant of quiet enjoyment... Our opinions concerning a constructive eviction by an alleged breach of an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment..."

Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.proposition: The covenant protects tenants from serious interferences with the tenancy that are caused by the landlord or are within the landlord’s control. See Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–51 (1997); Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473, 476–77 (2004).
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.support_reasoning: The opinion explains the nature of liability under the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment and emphasizes that liability arises where the landlord has at least negligent fault—typically by failing to address problems of which the landlord has notice and that foreseeably interfere with the tenant’s use of the premises. It notes that § 14 imposes liability when the natural and probable consequence of the landlord’s action or inaction is interruption of the tenant’s rights, and cites failures to repair known defects as classic violations. This aligns with the proposition that the covenant protects tenants from serious interferences with the tenancy caused by the landlord or within the landlord’s control.
Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850\u.relevant_excerpt: “We have also said that § 14 imposes liability whenever the ‘natural and probable consequence’ of a landlord’s action was interruption of the tenant’s rights. Simon v. Solomon, supra at 102, quoting Westland Hous. Corp. v. Scott, 312 Mass. 375, 381 (1942). In Cruz, we observed that the landlord had notice of the defects in the leased premises which it failed to repair, and that it was ‘wholly foreseeable’ that the injury to the tenant would result from this failure to make the repairs. Indeed, in each case since the 1973 statutory revision in which we have recognized a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, there was evidence that the landlord failed to act reasonably in the circumstances concerning a problem known to the landlord, and the natural and probable consequences of such failure caused the interference with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment of the premises.”

Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473, 476–77 (2004)
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The covenant protects tenants from serious interferences with the tenancy that are caused by the landlord or are within the landlord’s control. See Al-Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–51 (1997); Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct. 473, 476–77 (2004).
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly describes the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment as protecting tenants from “serious interferences with their tenancies” and applies that standard to a landlord’s knowing failure, over nine years, to correct a serious ventilation defect within the landlord’s control. The court holds that the landlord’s omissions, which caused ongoing moisture, odor, and ultimately a fire, required a finding of serious interference with and substantial impairment of the leased premises. This directly supports the proposition that the covenant protects against serious interferences caused by the landlord or within the landlord’s control.
Jablonski v. Clemons, 60 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The implied covenant of quiet enjoyment guarantees tenants the right to be free from ‘serious’ interferences with their tenancies. See G. L. c. 186, § 14… A landlord violates G. L. c. 186, § 14, when its ‘acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises.’… Here, the judge found that the landlord knowingly rented the premises in a defective condition and failed to correct the ventilation problem… for over nine years… On these facts… we think that the judge was required to find a serious interference with the tenancy and substantial impairment of the character and value of the leased premises.”

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 788–89 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: A landlord’s failure to correct substantial defects or sanitary code violations that significantly interfere with a tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Hemingway, 363 Mass. at 199–201; Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 788–89 (1994).
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The court squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to correct serious sanitary, building, and fire code violations—such as inadequate heat and hot water and vermin infestation—constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, § 14, i.e., a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. The opinion emphasizes that a landlord’s acts or omissions that foreseeably and substantially impair the value of the leased premises, including failure to repair known defects, are actionable under § 14. This directly supports the proposition that failing to correct substantial defects or code violations that significantly interfere with use and enjoyment breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: “Decisions from this court and from the Appeals Court clearly support the imposition of civil liability under § 14 in circumstances like those present in this case. In Ianello v. Court Management Corp., 400 Mass. 321, 323 (1987), it was said that a landlord violates § 14 when his acts or omissions impair the value of the leased premises.… A landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.… Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations… On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 203–04 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: Repeated water leaks, chronic dampness, and conditions conducive to mold growth that impair health or safety and substantially interfere with the tenant’s normal use of the premises constitute an “interference” within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14. See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 203–04 (1979) (unrepaired conditions and code violations); Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–04 (1982) (landlord liable for serious interferences with habitability and mental tranquility).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns breach of the implied warranty of habitability and the timing of rent abatement where there were losses of heat and hot water. It does not interpret or apply G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it discuss water leaks, chronic dampness, mold, or the concept of ‘interference’ under that statute. Using Berman & Sons for the specific § 14 interference proposition overreads the case; it is about strict liability and rent abatement for uninhabitable conditions (heat/hot water), not § 14 interference or mold-related conditions.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The Superior Court judge found there was insufficient evidence to conclude that the landlord acted intentionally, negligently, or in bad faith. He found and ruled that the losses of heat and hot water were material breaches of the warranty of habitability. The judge ruled further that the tenant is allowed to abate the rent from the date the landlord had notice of the breach of the warranty of habitability. We…hold that the tenant’s obligation abates as soon as the landlord has notice that premises fail to comply with the requirements of the warranty of habitability.”

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.proposition: Repeated water leaks, chronic dampness, and conditions conducive to mold growth that impair health or safety and substantially interfere with the tenant’s normal use of the premises constitute an “interference” within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14. See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 203–04 (1979) (unrepaired conditions and code violations); Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–04 (1982) (landlord liable for serious interferences with habitability and mental tranquility).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.support_reasoning: The case squarely holds that repeated flooding in a tenant’s apartment, caused by the landlord’s failure to maintain watertight, sanitary conditions, constitutes an interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, and that the landlord is liable for resulting personal injuries, including serious emotional distress. The court explicitly ties § 14 to “serious interferences” with the tenant’s tenancy and habitability, and upholds liability and attorneys’ fees based on chronic flooding conditions that impaired the tenant’s use of the premises and mental tranquility. Although the opinion does not focus on mold specifically, its reasoning clearly encompasses chronic dampness and similar health-impairing, habitability-threatening water conditions as statutory “interference.”
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102\u201.relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’… it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute. … Finally, Gem is liable to Solomon under G. L. c. 186, § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

Doe v. Boston Hous. Auth., 473 Mass. 788.support_reasoning: The provided text is not Doe v. Boston Hous. Auth. at all, but rather an opinion concerning arbitration and the scope of judicial review under the Massachusetts Uniform Arbitration Act. It does not discuss G.L. c. 186, § 14, the covenant of quiet enjoyment, constructive eviction, or abandonment. Doe v. Boston Hous. Auth., 473 Mass. 788.relevant_excerpt: Our reading of G. L. c. 251, §§ 11 through 13, to mean that a court will review an arbitrator’s award to determine only whether one of the statutory grounds for vacating, modifying, or correcting the award has been met accords with this court’s interpretation of the MAA since its enactment in 1960.
